Lack of credible news sources: The expert found no mention of the claim on any credible news website, indicating that the story was not published anywhere except in the form of the fabricated image.
Absence of genuine newspaper clipping: The image presented as a newspaper clipping was found to be fake and did not reflect an actual publication. This raises doubts about the authenticity of the claim.
Inaccurate identification of individuals: The individuals mentioned in the claim, such as William Askew Jr. and his late father, were not associated with Trump or his former school counselor position. The inclusion of stock photographs further undermines the credibility of the claim.
Lack of supporting evidence: Apart from the fake image, no additional evidence was provided to support the claim. The document mentioned in the claim was said to be in the process of authentication, suggesting that its authenticity was still uncertain.
